DIV1.P: BETTER LATE THAN NEVER A COMEDY.
BETTER LATE THAN NEVER A COMEDY.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL DRURY-LANE▪
LONDON: PRINTED FOR J. RIDGWAY, NO. 1, YORK-STREET, ST. JAMES'S-SQUARE.

DIV1.HEAD: TO HER GRACE The DUCHESS of LEEDS.
DIV1.P: THE Friendship which the Duke of Leeds has honoured me with for several years, in some Measure authorizes the Liberty I take of inscrib∣ing this Comedy to your Grace;—whilst the Favor he has so recently conferred upon me, by condescending to write a Prologue for my Play, makes me anxious to seize an early Opportunity of acknowledging to you, and to the World, how much I feel myself flatter'd by this Mark of his Regard.

The partial Encomiums, which your Grace be∣stowed upon my Comedy, when read last Winter amidst a private Circle of your Friends, led me to hope with some Degree of Confidence for that Success, which from the Indulgence of the Public, I have now experienced:—Sincerely wishing both
you and the Duke every domestic Enjoyment, and every permanent Happpiness, which your amiable Qualities so truly deserve, but which Rank and Fortune do not always ensure,

CLOSER.SALUTE: I have the Honor to be Madam, Your Grace's most Obedient And most devoted Servant,

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: TO the skilful Arrangement, and liberal Attention of Mr. Kemble, the Manager; the wonderful Exertions of Mrs. Jordan; and the united Abilities of all the Per∣formers, the Author is chiefly indebted for the Success of this Comedy.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE, WRITTEN BY HIS GRACE THE DUKE OF LEEDS.

LG.L: CUSTOM commands a Prologue to each Play;
But custom hath not told us what to say:
No form prescrib'd, 'tis difficult to find,
How to conciliate the Public mind.
The bashful Bard—the modest Muse's fears,
So long have jingled in your patient Ears,
That now, perhaps, you'll scarce vouchsafe to stay,
To hear both their Apology—and Play.
No! Better sure on him at once to call,
With—Sir, if frighten'd thus, why write at all?
We're not reduc'd yet to a trembling Pen;
Zounds, Bards, will croud us soon, like—Gentlemen.
Something like this, I heard a Friend once say,
Who wish'd (poor soul) to hear a new launch'd Play:
Box'd snug at first, completely to his mind,
With only one grave Auditor behind:
E'er the third Act had struggled to its end,
In reel'd three Critics, each the Author's Friend—
On Praise determin'd—Wit confirm'd by Wine;
Each And! and If! was chaste—correct—damn'd fine.
To Taste so mark'd, my Friend, of course, gave way;
But squeez'd, thump'd, kick'd—still listen'd to the Play;
Till by repeated Plaudits grown so Sore,
Nor Flesh nor Blood cou'd bear one Comment more.
Such boist'rous Friends they surely cannot need,
Who wish by Merit only to succeed.
To-night we offer to the Public view,
A Character, you'll own, perhaps, is new,
From Doctor's Commons we the Model draw;
A Promising Eleve of Civil Law;
And Civil sure that Law which can provide,
Or (shou'd need be) release you from a Bride.
Thrice bless'd the Mansion, where, in spite of ills
Alive or dead, you still can have your Wills.
Much cou'd I offer in our Author's cause;
Nay, prove his first great object—your applause;
But, least dull Friendship shou'd his Genius wrong,
I'll stop—before the Prologue grows too long,
And Better late than never hold my Tongue.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
A Breakfasting-Room in Saville's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Saville and Servant discovered. (A knocking without.)

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: SEE who's there, I'm not at home. [Exit Servant.] How strange, that, though I am sensible of my Error, I have not power to correct it—tho' I feel my Ruin, I have not Spirit to avoid it—wou'd I cou'd re∣cal—but 'tis impossible—Last night, compleated the loss of all my ready money, and if I cannot instantly raise more on my Estate—

SP.SPEAKER: Diary
SP.P: (without.) Not at home—don't tell me—I will see him; whether he be at home or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant
SP.P: (without.) I tell you my Master's not at home, coming here with your strange jumble of names which never met before.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: This can be nobody but Diary—Augusta's Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P:
Not at home, indeed; Why, do you think
I that have read Milton, and Roderic Random, and other historians, am to be deceiv'd by an ignorant—

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Patience, good Diary—I am very happy to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: Sir, I have brought you a letter, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: From Augusta?

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: No, Sir, from Mr. Flurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: From Mr. Flurry!

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: (Taking out a book and giving the letter) Yes, here it is safe enclosed in my dear Pamela; it has been there these two days, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Why then not favour me with it before?

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: 'Cause I was sadly 'fraid it wou'd make you melancholy; and they tell me you're already a cup too low, as old Saucer, the Poet, calls it.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Well, Diary, one must learn to brave mis∣fortunes. Let us see what the wise Star-gazer chooses to predict. (Reads)

LETTER.P: “Though my Ward, Augusta, is an Heiress, she can∣not marry without my Consent; and I am resolved she shall never be the Wife of a Libertine.”—

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: (Reading Pamela to herself). That Mr. B. was a wickd wretch, to be sure, tho' Miss Pamela might wear a check apron.

P.Q: “”I am sorry on account of your Uncle, my Friend Grump, and wish you were sorry on your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Diary
SP.P: (to herself.) What a sad thing it wou'd have been if he had succeeded!

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: How! do you come to mock at my distress, Diary?

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: Who, I come to mock—I assure you, Mr. Saville, there's no young woman in England enjoys distress more than I do: I never read a book that ends happily, if I know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P:
So, this is what I dreaded, tho' no more than I had reason to expect—by your being the bearer
of this letter, I am to suppose your lovely Mistress agrees with her Guardian.

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, she is quite agreable—as we say—you have so often promis'd to reform, and so often broke your promise,—that—

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: True, Diary; but whatever I may feel, I have still pride enough to applaud her conduct, and con∣demn my own—tell her so, Diary, and tell her besides, tho' I have adored her from life's early period, and whilst I have breath can never cease to love her; yet—but no matter—'tis now too late—

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: Never too late to mend, Sir.—Lord, he's a great General, as they said of Sir Isaac Newton.—[Aside] It grieves me to part with him—Oh! Mr. Saville, if you knew all—

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Knew what, Diary?

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: What I have seen, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Well, what have you seen?

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: Oh! such things, Sir—but it is not my business to tell secrets, else I know what I know, and when people talk in their sleep, I guess what they wou'd be at—as Lothario—the Fair Penitent says.—Good bye to you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, explain a little—but perhaps—farewel, good Diary.

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: He's a sweet man—as Juliet says to Old Capillaire, in the Play—Ah! Mr. Saville—if you had been my lover—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Servant with a Coat and Waistcoat.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: What wou'd you have done, my kind friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: Any thing you had pleas'd, as your great old ladies did, Juno and Proserpine, and Jane Shore did—stand out of the way. Lord he's a dear fellow, and if my Mistress had ran away with him, we shou'd have all got into a novel together.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Good day, Mrs. Diary, what still on the same tune, Eh?

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: Ah! we have play'd it for the last time, Sir. Adieu Mr. Saville. Out of the way Varlet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: What, the happy day is fix'd at last Sa∣ville!

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Happy, Sir. This is no time for raillery—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: No faith—Marriage is too serious a subject to joke on, but if it stings you now, what will it do hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Oh, Sir Charles, I have lost a Treasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Lost a Treasure—When?

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Now—this very moment—the best of Women.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: A Woman—thank Heaven it's no worse. I thought you had lost the other half of your Fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Fortune! I have lost Augusta—the source—the summit of my hopes.—Read that letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles
SP.P: (reads). Why how has this happen'd—you are not more of a libertine than you were.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: But am I not more involv'd? Is not my fortune squander'd—gone—am I not discarded by my Uncle, the only relation I have that can assist me—without friends—almost without resource.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Nay, never droop man—write to your Uncle, promise reformation—talk of prudence and parsimony—get him to raise the wind—and then for another venture: fortune you know must wheel about.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Sir Charles, you revive me. I'll not give way to despondence—I will write to my Uncle—tho' what hopes can I entertain from such an avaricious dis∣position—mean while I have scarce a guinea to throw n the way of the blind Goddess, were she inclin'd to favour me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Don't let that distress you—tho' I have not the means, our new Friend will be here in an instant, and he is both liberal and capable.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Our new Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P:
Yes, the Young Hussar officer with the wound in his forehead, who, from his long residence
abroad, has been stiled the Chevalier.—See here he is, and as gay and lively as ever.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Augusta, in an Hussar dress, singing.
Care flies from the lad that is merry, &c.
DIV3.P: How fares it, my Heroes—heh!—melancholy, Saville, What's the matter with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Hush!—don't interrupt him—he's thinking.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Thinking! Sure he can't be so unfashion∣able. What, turn'd Philosopher, Saville?

SP.SPEAKER: Saville,
SP.P: No, Chevalier—I wish I cou'd—but every man ruminates on his losses, and mine are irrecover∣able.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Not if money will replace them. Come, come, my friend, you lost a few thousands last night, I won them, and if the loan will assist you, you may command me.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Are you serious?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Aye, serious as a Philosopher.—Here—in this pocket-book are notes for near 5,000l. take and make the most of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: What, without thinking when and how you are to be repaid.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Thinking again, Saville—psha!—what's the use of thinking?—true Genius is above it—it al∣ways acts by instinct: so take the money, and if you wou'd oblige me, say no more about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Hark ye, Chevalier, if instinct will prompt you to find another pocket-book—give it to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Why this is the most extraordinary act, Chevalier, but without you name some mode of re∣payment, upon my honour, I cannot accept—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Stop! I'll settle the difference. You seem not to want the money, and he seems not to want the security: now I want the money, and have no security to give. So the business is settled at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P:
Well, Chevalier, rather than our friend's archness shou'd have no effect, I will accept your offer on one condition—instantly take my bond, payable in
three days, and by that time, if my Lawyer has not deceiv'd—aye, my Estate will be sold, and I shall be in possession of thrice the sum.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Well, if you will have it so—

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Nay, I will have it no other way—I'll go and prepare the bond this instant. Sir Charles, you will be kind enough to—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Oh, leave me to manage where any thing is to be got [aside to Saville, who goes out]. Bravo, my dear Cousin, Augusta—bravo—you play your part ex∣cellently; in this disguise it is impossible he shou'd know you—why I scarce know you myself. Let me look at you.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Hush! this further supply will draw him deeper in the toils—for if he plays again and loses—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Which he certainly will.—I have se∣cur'd the loaded Dice.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: And I have secur'd the Lawyer—the very man he has employed to raise him more money, is my particular friend—so when I can get the Deeds, the Property, and the Estate, into my own hands—my purpose is effected.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: But do you seriously wish to compleat his ruin?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Seriously.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Aye, there's the mystery—one day or other you shall know—in the mean time be assur'd I love him more than ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Then why not marry him?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: What, to prevent the flame from increas∣ing—heh! Mr. Joker—no—no—besides my Guar∣dian will not consent, or, if he wou'd, my heart and fortune wou'd both be squander'd away upon a des∣perate Game of Chance. With submission, I must have better security for my affection, than your loaded Dice, Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Well, it's not my affair—only remem∣ber our agreement—I am to assist you in stripping him; and you are to help me in improving my ward∣robe.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Without doubt—if thro' your means I succeed in the enterprize, you shall receive my warmest thanks; and a pocket-book into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Shall I!—then here I swear eternal obedience, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: How, on your knees, Sir Charles!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: On my knees—I cou'd fall prostrate at the feet of the Chevalier, for his generosity to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Certainly! I owe him every grateful ac∣knowledgement; but I never prostrate myself, except to the ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: You are right, Saville—I never desire to see you so, but in that capacity.—Oh! this is the bond is it; and now, I hope, your cares are at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Would they were!

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Heavens! what a sigh was there; why sure you are not in love?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Not in love; why, poor fellow—he has just receiv'd his Coup de Grace—the Lady has seen somebody she likes better—perhaps you, or me, Che∣valier.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: As you say, she may have seen me; and who knows but I may be as likely to please her as any body else.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Very true, upon my honour—the Lady is my relation; and if you wish to be acquaint∣ed, I'll introduce you whenever you please—indeed, she's a very charming girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Sir, I have not the least doubt of the lady's perfections.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: The whole world can have but one opinion of Augusta.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Nay, she is a perfect Angel—me∣thinks I see her now before me—with her arch look, and roguish leer—such charming talents—such vivacity with so much feeling.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta
SP.P:
(looking in a pocket glass). Egad, you colour so strongly, that I cou'd fancy I saw her too; but that
I am sure the picture is too flattering.—Will you walk, Sir Charles—Saville, we shall meet at dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Yes, the club are to dine with me—I shall expect you both.—Chevalier, this loan of yours, has given me new life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Yes, and it will give the club new life too.—Adieu, Saville—Don't lose your spirits man.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: No none of your woe-begone looks;—but put on a chearful countenance.—Zounds, love—I laugh at it. I know no woman I like better than myself. Lookye, I'll stand your friend, Saville: Sir Charles shall introduce me to the cruel fair one; and if I don't laugh her into something, say I am not the Chevalier—that's all my boy; if I don't make her resume herself—say I'm not the Chevalier.—Come along Baronet. (Exit with Sir Charles.)

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: What a fine generous madcap fellow it is. With this temporary relief, I'll try once more to re∣cover;—if I succeed, Augusta may still be mine. Who knows what Fortune may yet have in store for me.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
Flurry discovered looking through a Telescope—a great Folio Book open before him.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Twelve signs of the Zodiac—Aye, twelve—Let me see, Arus, one—Tarus, two—Gimini, three.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: There's my delectable husband—with his head full of nothing, but stars and comets, as thick as he's long, yet fancying himself in a decline.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Gimini, three—Canker, four—Virago, five.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Mr. Flurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Virago five—there she is—No, she is n't—Yes, she is—Mercy on me—What a tail.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: He raves,—will you hear me, Mr. Flurry. (very loud)

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Oh! dear, my wife's voice—She's so bois∣terous. Will you never consider my poor nerves.—I'm already in a gallopping consumption.—Where's my Sal Volatile.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Where's your senses, rather say.—Will you never leave off these nostrums, and nonsense? What's the use of gazing all day after a comet? If it should appear, do you think it will pay you for peep∣ing?

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Not if I estimate it from you, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: I have not patience.—If I was not the best wife in the world, I should run distracted—I should never survive it.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Shou'd'nt you? What hopes then for me, if you were not quite so good a wife as you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Don't distress yourself on that ac∣count any longer. I can't see why my youth should be wasted, any my natural endowments lost, where there is neither taste to relish, or anxiety to preserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: You surely can't say that I want anxiety, my life. I have had nothing else since I knew you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Then the portion shall be doubled, my life. Do you hear that?

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Oh, Thunder! I fear I shall never hear again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Yes, you will, you will hear, that your ward, Augusta, is going to throw herself away upon a young rake.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: So would all your sex, if they had the op∣portunity. A rake is your delight, and his youth your excuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: His youth our excuse! Then I am an exception to the rule; for I have thrown myself away, without any such apology to plead.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Well, well, I have no doubt of preventing her flights; and, perhaps, I may be able to remedy yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P:
I scorn your insinuation and your menace; and trust I may enjoy the innocent pleasures
of fashionable life, without endangering my reputa∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Oh! certainly wife, certainly; nothing can be so innocent as fashionable life: but though you don't see your danger, I can feel my own. My friend Grump has opened my eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: What, Sir, is my character to be can∣vass'd by such a mean, pitiful, old miser, as Grump? A wretch to traduce me, with his covetous whims, and short sentences—as careful of his words as of his money.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump
SP.P: (without). Will, come up I say—Will—that's enough (Enters).

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Welcome, neighbour Grump. You just come in time to stop my wife's mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Stop a hurricane!—Can't be done, old Shake-about. (Slaps Flurry on the back, and breaks his bottle.)

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: A hurricane indeed; I'm shook to shivers.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: What, broke your bottle totteration. So much the better—teach you to be wiser;—wrap up in whitey brown—can't break that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Very neat, and vastly civil.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Don't mind civility—only picks a man's pocket.—Well, what say you—give Augusta to my nephew.—Had a good fortune once—may have again.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Can't possibly think of it, neighbour.—I sent him my positive refusal—He is such a spend∣thrift and a rake-shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Take a wife to tame him—nothing else can.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: What, Sir, do you judge from your∣self? Do you look upon every husband as a brute—to be tam'd by his wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Brute—aye—first, or last—seldom escapes.—Advise Flurry to be careful.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Oh, dear—why put a man in mind of his misfortunes.—I must take a little Daffy.—Will you have a taste?

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P:
Physic the dogs—hate an apothecaries
shop▪—colour'd brick dust—and white chalk.—What's this?—Stare at the sun.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Pray Heaven he may break that to pieces (aside).

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: At the sun, neighbour—No—the comet' tail.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Tale of a Tub—all fudge—got something else to make you stare—Send away Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Indeed I shall not stay to be dismiss'd—but like my betters, will take leave to retire. So, Mr. Longhead and Mr. Wronghead, you wise cabi∣net counsellors, adieu. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Happy riddance—Well—here it is—Read your fate, old Tremble—here's a tale for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: What will it touch us, do you think?

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Touch you, yes, pretty nearly:—A kind paragraph in the paper—knew it wou'd get there at last—listen.—(Reads) “If a certain buxom lady, of a thick, punch, fanciful, water-gruel husband,”—Do you mind that?

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: It quite disorders ones frame.—Go on.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: “”Makes assignations with baronets, near an eminent painter's in Marlborough-street.—The exact place of meeting shall be publicly stated."

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Mercy on me—I am quite relax'd.—An eminent painter—that must mean my friend Pallet—I'll go there this instant—He'll tell me if there's any house of intrigue near him. I'll go there—that I will. (Goes and returns)—But suppose it should be all a lie.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Aye—but truth's as cheap as lies;—besides, see what a picture they have drawn of you—thick, punch, fanciful—water-gruel husband—Must be you, like as two peas.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Litigamus with Parchment and Papers.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Make bold to intrude—but ask pardon for the offence—Reverend sirs, believe I have never had the superlative honour of spreading parchments for either, but if my information is right—one of you two must e the happy man.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Think you seem the happiest of the bunch—little parchment spreader. Who the devil are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: A proctor, at your service—write—draw, scrawl, scribble—dash—&c.—Can fill a skin with the tightest—a licence—or a will.—All the same to Litigamus—Marriage or death—both necessary evils. Permit me to have the honour of setting your name down in the divorce list. (to Grump.)

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Can't be set down—have no honour for you—there's the happy man—told you so—Old Horn∣beam. All the world knows of your good fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Gracious! what will become of me—Pray Mr. Lit—tit—gamus, what brought you to my house?

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: My own lucky stars.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Stars! Oh then you came here perhaps—to tell us about the comet?

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Comet! no! no!—that's too remote for my practice; some bright luminaries, that blaze close at hand best suit my purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Blaze, close at hand!—Oh lud! Oh lud!

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Yes, my business is to make discoveries of a nearer kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Nearer—what in the moon?

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: The moon—no—nor the man in the moon neither—by moonlight sometimes—tho' my satellites mostly shine in the dark—But here's my almanack (taking out another newspaper)—and if I am right—as I said before—you are the happy man.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump
SP.P: (reads). Yes—just such an almanack as mine—foretells the same event—same bill of fare.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Bill of fare—where?

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Where—Horn Tavern—Doctors Com∣mons.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Yes, that's the place for action—no time to be lost such a handsome—good looking Gentle∣man to be so treated—Doctors Commons is the place—Citation—Jactitation—Excommunication, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Botheration—I think too Mr. Cetera—What can this handsome, good-looking gentleman do.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Might I presume to recommend, nameless—I wou'd say—no body more alert, active, bright—quick at proof—clear in statement—nice in terms—I forbear to expatiate on myself—but only give the cue—in a week you shall be involv'd—in a fortnight altogether by the ears—thoroughly exposed in less than a month▪ and a compleat happy man in a quarter.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: There's expedition—only give the cue.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Mery on me, I have no cue to give—I know no more of my wife than you do—If we could but consult the stars.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: You had better consult the civilians.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Yes, stare at a proctor—odd looking thing enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Thing! Mr. Roughcast—aye, and the best thing a husband has to trust to.—We fight his battles, and pepper his adversary without endangering his own noddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: No occasion, wife takes care of his head before hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Let Madam, do her worst—the stronger the proof, the sooner he becomes a happy man—don't be uneasy, Sir,—I have not the smallest doubt of your success—facts clear as day—evidence ocular and auri∣cular—the lady totally done up, and yourself the most pitiable object in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Oh my nerves—my poor nerves! I must have something to take, where's my dalmahoy? Oh! oh! oh! oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: (taking one arm). Take my arm—sweet, Sir. I'm a specific always at hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump
SP.P: (seizing the other). Come, tumble on, Old Scarecrow.—Here's a coat of arms for you; antlers for a crest—and a proctor for one of the supporters.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
Pallet's House: a Room with Pictures—large whole length of Mrs. Flurry, in a Conspicuous Situation.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: A VERY fine woman indeed, as I us'd to say to my wife. I wonder who she can be; my good friend Sir Charles Chouse, who introduc'd her here for a touch of my art, has never yet favour'd me with her name—wonder at that too—as I am in most of the Baronet's secrets—but great men have their mysteries, and seldom open the budget, without a little reserve at bottom.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles
SP.P: (without). Your master is quite alone, is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Oh! here comes the Prime Minister him∣self!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Pallet, my old boy, I am glad to see thee. How goes business?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Always ready for employment, as I us'd to say to Mrs. Pallet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Aye, you're a d—mn'd wicked, good sort of a fellow, that's the truth of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: I rejoice to find you so early abroad—before, as I may say, the sun has risen, or the nobility got up—but—indeed, the morning air makes gentlemen look as if they wou'd live for ever.—As a painter, I quite rejoice.—As a physician, I shou'd die myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: True, Pallet—I believe I do look toler∣ably; but thou hast a pretty way of touching up a picture—What think you of my fair friend on your anvass there?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: A fine subject, indeed, for a brush—exqui∣site complexion, charming features, beautiful locks, and a rich prospect in the back ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Take great care then—that she is not canvass'd elsewhere.—Mum, is the word.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Mute as my own Pallet—people who talk only betray secrets, and talking of talking; I know when it's proper not to talk at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Betwixt ourselves—She is actually a married woman; whose husband is as rich as Croesus, and who knows but, with a little management, I may be able to dip in the same purse. She is confoundedly virtuous at present—but she has a damn'd deal of dis∣cernment, and that's all in my favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Yes, she will soon improve in good com∣pany, indeed she begins to appear like a woman of fashion already; for she talks loud, tho' she has no∣thing to say—forever in a bustle, tho' she has nothing to do; and beyond all, thinks she excels in painting.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: So she does—you may see that in her countenance; but the best of the joke is—that, tho' I have been acquainted with her some time, I have never once seen her husband.—She tells me—he is always sick, and I am not sorry—

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry
SP.P: (without). Hey!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Heh!—who have we here—take no notice of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Servant! servant, Mr. Pallet—I wanted a little word with you; but I am so heated, I can scarce speak—I have such a woman upon my hands—heh! Who's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Only a discreet friend of mine—nobody you have occasion to be afraid of.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Well then, as I can rely on you, I want to ask your advice. Pray do you know of a conve∣nient house hereabouts, where people—you understand me—might meet together if they choose it?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet
SP.P:
[Aside]. A woman upon his hands—conve∣nient house—sure he don't mean mine—or perhaps he
does want such a little snug retreat—(to him) Why, Sir, there are such places, I believe, to be met with—but you, who are a sober married man—would wish, I presume, to have a curtain drawn over the exhibition.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Curtain drawn! Me in an exhibition—you suffocate me; sure you can't think I want such a place myself!

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Dear me—I beg pardon. Like to have a sad mistake [aside]. But talking of wants, pray, may I ask, what it is you do want?

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Why, I have seen a wicked story in the papers, which I am anxious to have confirm'd—about a bad house in your neighbourhood.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: In my neighbourhood?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Yes, near an eminent painter, in Marl∣borough-street.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: An eminent painter—that, indeed, can mean only me—Gad very near blowing myself [aside]. Sir, I can assure you, I know of no bad house at all—this Gentleman can vouch for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I—I—Yes,—I can vouch for it—It's word for word, as he states it.—Pray what were you talking of—I hope I don't interrupt business.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: No, I wish you did interrupt business—I have some reason to suspect a lady of mine being too partial to a dissipated rake of a baronet—Don't you think it very rascally, sir, in a man of fashion, to at∣tack any gentleman's wife, who is a quiet peaceable, good sort of man, and attacks no body.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Shocking indeed, sir.—What say you Pallet?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Oh dreadful, and so sweet, so gentleman like a gentleman—a gentleman who is incapable of using any other gentleman so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Most shameful! have you any idea of the gallant?

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Oh no! but they tell me it's one of your idle fellows about town—and an ill looking dog I hear; but are you sure, there is no such house of meeting hereabouts.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Nothing of the kind I can venture to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Aye, it's all an impudent lie, I suppose—well, that's a cordial indeed—This is a sweet pretty house of yours, Mr. Pallet. Some charming pictures too.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Happy in such a connoisseur to commend.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: You know I promis'd you shou'd draw my wife's picture some day or other—heh! zounds—what the devils that I see? there she is—why you've got my wife at full length—O heavens! I shall faint—where's my Dalmahoy?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: The devil—his wife—this is certainly Flurry himself.—

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: To be sure it is.—Why wou'd not you mention his name before?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: What a discovery!—Zounds, exert your ingenuity, make some damn'd good lie or other.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: I'll try—(Aside) Ha! ha! ha!—My good friend, Mr. Flurry, so it's like your wife is it—Ah! poor Mrs. Jenkyns—It's rather a flatt'ring likeness, tho' I shou'd suppose—but I have a way of making my pictures like every body.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Gad, so you have Pallet—very like—poor Mrs. Tompkins. Now I observe. I know her at once—

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Tompkins—Jenkins!—What is all this? I may as well take another look—aye, there is some difference now I perceive,—no, it can't be my wife, she cou'd never get here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: My dear Mr. Pallet, have you finish'd my picture?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Hush!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: What is the matter—I tell you sir Charles is very impatient, he says it is not half hand∣some enough—Oh dear Sir Charles are you there?

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: (advancing) Yes, and I am here, and you are here, and Mrs. Jenkyns is here, and we are all here—Oh! Mr. Pallet, you are a pretty man, and this discreet friend of yours is I suppose, the ill look∣ing dog that I was caution'd against—Yes, now I see it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: For heaven's sake Mr. Flurry, how can you expose yourself before strangers.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: I believe it is you that expose me, but not before strangers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Now to bring her off. (aside) Upon my honour, I feel myself extremely chagrin'd to be the innocent cause of sewing dissentions between so deserving a couple; but wishing to have a portrait of my deceased friend, Mrs. Jenkyns.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Why just now you call'd her Tomkins.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: No, no, Jenkins.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Oh! Jenkins.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: The late widow Jenkins, and hearing your fair lady resembled her in features, I prevailed on her good nature to sit for an hour or two, that's the whole affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Yes, a perfect sketch, drawn by a master.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: I had best pursue the hint (aside). Well, if this is to be the consequence of my wish to oblige, Mr. Flurry may break his heart e'er he shall find me good natur'd again.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: I don't recollect—I ever found you so be∣fore.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Let me persuade you, Sir, not to put wrong constructions on the most harmless—

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: A mere dash of the pencil, effac'd in a mo∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: A circumstance that happens every day.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: No sooner seen than blotted out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: The first families in town—

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Flock to my house continually, and no one ever presumed to call it in question.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: This is the bad house—I've found it out—this is the place of assignation—have had my scouts at work, my client—the parchments are filling, and your exposure will follow immediately—Oh! these I suppose are the parties concern'd—an amicable suit perhaps—quite the same thing to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Why, who the devil are you, and what is your business here?

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: My business is every where, never out of my way; if parties are adverse, there am I—if amica∣ble, here stands Liti—a wedding, or a divorce, abuse or praise—fill but the parchment—enough for the proctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Stop his mouth Pallet—Gad, this friend of your's Mr. Flurry, is a very facetious fellow, ha! ha! a very pleasant fellow indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Yes, he came to my house pleasantly and told me a very pleasant story, advis'd a pleasant mode of redress, and now seems as pleasant about it as if no∣thing had happen'd—Don't you think so my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Yes, my dear, a very pleasant busi∣ness altogether.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: (to Pallet) Sir Charles, a generous client you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: (to Litig.) As a prince—besides he wants nothing of the lady but a little loose cash perhaps, that he may reward his friends the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig
SP.P: (to Pallet). Always open to conviction, and love to prevent animosities.—(To the company) A very whimsical mistake indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: What you are in the mistake too?

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Oh yes.—Nothing so common in practice; my friend Mr. Pallet assures me, there cannot be a more striking likeness, than the one to the other, and dare say, Mr. Flurry is perfectly convinced that Mr. Tomkins, Jenkyns, what's his name, was a most de∣sirable woman, and shou'd my client wish for the pic∣ture—

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Oh don't mention it; I never desire to see their likeness again, let's be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Well, de Mortuis nil—please you an arm for each, Between man and wife, who so proper to di∣rect the path—lead them right—tread lightly o'er—(Treads accidently on Flurry's toe.)

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Oh dear—I shall never tread again—I have no foot left. I shall sink—Oh! oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P:
Ask ten thousand pardons—a little too heavy—Servant gentlemen, (sees Sir Charles, and
Mrs. Flurry, ogling each other) there, you see how it is—All will be well again from top to toe.
SP.STAGE: Exeunt Flurry, Mrs. Flurry, and Litig.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: This cursed picture has been very un∣fortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: An unlucky stroke, but pretty well var∣nish'd over.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: That quivering fool will never suffer his wife to come here again, and he and his proctor together may so watch her motions, that I despair of getting a separate interview.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: It's hard upon us artists, that a lady mayn't set where she pleases.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Therefore I'm determin'd to execute a plan which I have sometime had in my head; will you assist?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Doubtless.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: You have heard of your brother pain∣ter, doctor Hubble bubble▪

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: What the great man who cures by a look?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Yes, that makes the dumb to roar a catch, and teaches the gouty to dance a hornpipe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Oh! Sir Charles, he's a most wonderful genius.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: True! then what do you think of passing for him?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: I—imitate the great man—impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Why so—I'm sure you are quite as wonderful a fellow—I'll be your assistant.—Go and procure us a couple of suitable disguises.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Egad, quite new—hitherto I have only painted others—I must now go and try to paint my∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Lose no time—at present, I have an∣other engagement on my hands.—Adieu—I've no doubt of success as I've such a damn'd wicked good sort of a fellow for an ally. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Yes,—I'm up to any thing, as I us'd to say to Mrs. Pallet. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
An Apartment in Saville's House—Large folding Doors.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: You shall come back.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: No, while I have my senses, I'll keep them.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Keep your senses! psha!—don't you wish to be on a footing with the rest of the company.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Faith, I am not so ambitious—I hate wine.—You forgot I have lived abroad, Saville—I can't sit like a dull Englishman, a whole afternoon, grinning at table jokes, and prosing over politics—My mind is active—all life and fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Come, come, confess, you are going to sigh away the evening with some fair incognita.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: With a woman, Saville—No, hang it—that wou'dn't answer my purpose.—If Sir Charles does not come soon, the scheme is undone. (Aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Where are you going then!

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Oh! Perhaps to judge of the play, by a lounge in the lobby—or enjoy the Opera, by a strut in the coffee-room—or else, take a nap in the gallery of the House of Commons, to prove my patriotism;—in short, like the bulk of mankind, any where to avoid reflection.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: That's just my own case—follow my ex∣ample—if you would avoid reflection, the best re∣medy is at hand, to lose sight of care—take a bumper my boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: You are wrong there—that's the way to see it double.—If the man hates thinking—send him to me—The only reflecting thing in my house is a looking-glass.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P:
Well, Saville as our friend Sir Charles is here, I've no objection to return for a few minutes;—but remember our agreement—No play for me.—A
word, Sir Charles—Are the false dice ready—are we sure of success? (Aside to Sir Charles.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Yes, my confederates are in the next room, and my life on't, we strip him of the last shil∣ling.—(Aside to Aug.) Come let's dispatch—See the lads are at it already—the bones are in motion.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Are they? Then flesh and blood can't re∣sist—and now Chevalier, we'll lose sight of reflection forever. [Exit to company thro' the folding doors.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Got a letter from my nephew—Come, to see if it's true—(Reads.)

LETTER.P: "I am sensible of my error—grown quite another being—live with friends as prudent at yourself. Fa∣vour me with a little supply, to forward the reforma∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Prudent as myself—can't be—however something in it, perhaps;—wish to be good natur▪d—lend him a guinea.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: So, they are already deeply engag'd—and I have given them the slip—while he is pigeon'd it's better I should be out of the way.—Who have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: One of the prudent set, I suppose—not much like me though—Pump him:—Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Servant old Truepenny; what brings you here—warrant in your pocket—arrest the word, heh!

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Yes, that's the word—don't like it, may∣hap. Where's my nephew?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: His nephew! as I live, old Grump. He is rich, and I may assist Saville, without injuring my my own designs (aside.) Oh, Sir, I ask ten thou∣sand pardons; your nephew is quite an alter'd man.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Hear o—begins to reform.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta
SP.P: Begins—fiinish'd! He has already shun'd all his old friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: That's right—hate old friends; apt to borrow money.—Don't much like new ones.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: A wise maxim, Sir, therefore I should be happy to borrow a little, as being neither one nor t'other; for betwixt ourselves, your nephew is grown so close of late—

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Think he is—keeps close in his hole—Why not come out?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: No, I mean close fisted, penurious, wary. I dare say he outdoes you in every thing:—you keep no servants, perhaps, and only starve yourself;—now he keeps several, and starves them and himself too.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Starves them, does he? Then you are not one of his keeping, that's certain. However, if he is so miserable, step on—enjoy it with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Stop! stop! You hav'n't heard all yet—He is grown excessively fond of study, and is at this moment up to the elbows in Blackstone.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: What Law! heh! Don't like it—keep out of the way—interrupt him, perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Yes, you had better come another time. Good-day, Mr. Grump—I give you joy, your nephew is grown quite studious—Good bye to you—so stu∣dious, so peaceful, so quiet—Your very humble ser∣vant.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Aye, call another time—Paid my visit—sav'd a guinea. Servant—glad to find every thing so quiet. (Going,)
Ha! what's all that?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Plague take their clamour, (More noise.)

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: What, Hell broke loose? Blackstone in a passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Stay, Sir, I'll explain the whole affair:—The fact is this—Men of the first character and learn∣ing, who countenance your nephew, are met in the next room, to discuss literary subjects.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P:
Literati; what in blue stockings, heh!
aye—Laugh at their own jokes; never at any body's else.—Take one peep at the blue stockings, however.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Stop, Sir—for Heaven's sake, Sir, stop! If they see you, they may grow desperate; they may lampoon you—write your life.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Write my life! so much the better—get into good company; shine in the tete-a-tetes.—Will take a peep.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Charles, from folding doors.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Joy! give me joy, Chevalier—I have carried off the golden fleece. I have won every thing. Here, here, my friend, here's you cash again, and his notes for as much more.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Stop your tongue—Don't you see?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: See, yes, I do see, and a fine looking fellow it is; just one of us. Come, take a round, Trusty—'slife you shall enter—and get as drunk as the rest of the party.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Drunk! What, Literati get drunk?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: No, no, he means intoxicated with science, and flush'd with the heat of argument—don't you, Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I mean flush'd with the juice of the grape, and as drunk as piper s

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Why you've lost your senses.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Not he—can't lose what he never had—Smoke, the whole.—Literati, indeed!—button my pockets.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, you misunderstand him: they may have been drinking a little to quicken their fancy, and deciding their controversial subjects by betting.—Nothing so common, is it Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: You never were more out in your life; come along with me, old Crabstick, and I'll give you ocular proof, proof positive, my Trojan. There—seven's the main, and nothing's the chance;—now are you satisfied?

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Yes, see how they starve themselves.—Off while I'm safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P:
Nay, you must not go thus, my little
Money Flincher; they are all so mad, you might pick their pockets without being discover'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Might I—not a bad halfpenny amongst them, though—Get my own pick'd perhaps, hang'd into the bargain. No, off while I can.—(Laughs) Good bye, Literati. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: So, you have amus'd yourself to some purpose: You don't know Saville's uncle, old Grump, when you see him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: No; never saw him in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Except this instant, that you frighten'd him away, when I had persuaded him of Saville's re∣formation.—'Slife, though I have my motives for ruining him, there's no reason why I should not keep his uncle as a corps de reserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Don't be vex'd at my talking more than yourself; but step in, and enjoy the victory—Ha! here he comes; I must to my physical scheme on old Flurry. Adieu, my sweet cousin; what you wou'd be at, heaven knows; only two things I am sure of; you love mystery, and I love money; and so, as he has none at present left to lose, fare you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Confusion! Day after day, the same unwea∣ried persecution—never one fortunate hour. You here, Sir (To Augusta.) As you would not be pre∣sent while we play'd, I think you might have avoided witnessing your friend's defeat.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Why so? One may hurt less than t'other.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville,
SP.P: How, Sir, is this a time for mirth?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Nay, don't be angry, Saville; when a man has lost his senses, he can't expect to keep his money you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Death and fire, keep your temper, Sir; re∣strain your warmth.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P:
Warmth, Saville; I never was cooler in
my life; and what's more, I believe you'll never find a way to warm me.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Look ye, Sir, I have lost some thousands; and if you'll be temperate. (Aug. sings.) Temperate I say, Sir, for one moment! Distraction! Will you hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Why I do, I do hear you.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Then out of pure good nature—merely out of good nature, I will give you a throw for five thousand.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Nay, Saville, I never game; besides it would be playing for nothing—you have none of the ready left.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Then by heavens, I'll be calm no longer: Hark'e, Sir, you add insult to my despair; and here I tell you I have been dup'd—dup'd by knaves and cheats.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Cheats! Zounds! I hope you don't allude to me, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I suspect you were in the com∣bination; and to be plain, Sir, I have no doubt, but you advanc'd the money only to ensnare me; and if you do not instantly give me a chance of retrieval, I will proclaim you to the world a thief and an impostor.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta
SP.P: (aside). Oh lord! no body near—I'm frighten'd to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Come, Sir, I have call'd you impostor.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: No, you hav'n't—indeed you hav'n't.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Then I add coward to the stigma, and now I am resolv'd on having satisfaction, one way or other. Come, Sir, no evasion—the sword or the dice.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Oh lord, Sir, I never gave a Gentleman satisfaction in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Mean, dastardly wretch, defend yourself this instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta
SP.P: (kneeling). Oh! have pity, Sir, if you'll be calm, I'll give you a thousand pounds—

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: A thousand devils!—Give me a fair chance.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump
SP.P: (without). Tell him not to write any more—won't pay postage. [Enters.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta
SP.P: (rising). D—mn you, Sir, what do you mean by offering me a thousand pounds. (draws and offers to fight.) [Saville retires.
Come on, I say, Sir.—What, you've had enough have you; Damme, I knew—I shou'd humble you.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: What, young flash away turn'd duellist!

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Sir, I have been so insulted, that I shall leave the house while I can keep my temper. Mr. Saville, if you can shake off your natural timidity, you will let me hear from you; if not, I shall be ob∣lig'd to expose you, I shall, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Fine fellow! lick some of my debtors into payment—What George! Literati, too fierce, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Sir, this is no time for explanation.—As for you, mean wretch as you are, think not to escape my resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: What, you can bully now! Sir, if you'll believe me, when you came, the hectoring combatant you now see, was down on his knees for pity, offering a thousand pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Aye, aye, great bully I warrant—not worth so many pence.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, he wou'd have frighten'd any other man out of his senses—but I, Sir,—I have humbled him—come, go about your business, I pardon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Pardon me! but you are too contemptible for notice. Dear Uncle, permit me to retire for a moment to recollect myself. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Contemptible, indeed.—'Sblood I'll fol∣low and chastise him this instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P: Great mind to let him—the dog deserves it—no—spare him this time; walk with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Well, Sir, out of mere respect to you—else—zounds—if I did'n't know you'd prevent me, I'd—But no matter, I am cool.

SP.SPEAKER: Grump.
SP.P:
That's right, more adapted to Literati;
come walk side by side—there now (cocking his little old hat)—two hero's together. Od! lick the world—heh! Brother, Alexander.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Yes, my little Clytus, when you come to know me, you'll find that I'm a match for any man; if I choose to engage with him. [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
A Room in an Old House, with Electrical and Magnetical Apparatus.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Charles and Pallet in Disguise, as a Doctor and his Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: BRAVO, Master Pallet! Excellent—how well one painter can copy another. You look like the real Doctor Hubblebubble himself. I always said you had a good knack at disguise. What think you of me for your journeyman?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Not an apothecary's 'prentice in town can be better prepar'd for a pestle and mortar; and, with submission, I may say, disguise sits natural upon us both.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I have borrow'd this old house, and provided the trumpery that you see, to give a better colour to the plan.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: But are you sure, Flurry will venture hi∣ther?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Quite certain; I knew he had heard of Dr. Hubblebubble's late fame in magnetism, and other modern wonders; therefore sent him a line in the Doctor's name, assuring him that he wou'd make a complete cure of him, gratis, for the sake of his own reputation. You may easily imagine our valetudina∣rian bit at the proposal.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: No doubt; but how can I bite him when he comes? my brother, brush, may understand something of physic; but I confess myself quite a novice in the science.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Novice! so much the better; what signifies science in this age; puff your own ignorance, take advantage of the credulous, and you are sure to have a multitude at your heels. You must talk to him in High Dutch.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: I cou'd as soon converse with him in Chi∣nese.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: No matter, any jargon will suffice—his folly will keep pace with yours, I warrant you.—Do but detain him here, till I can have an interview with Madam, and the business is done.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry
SP.P: (without). Ha! Hem!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Hush! here he comes—to your studies—adjust your perriwig, and fix your brow.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry
SP.P: (without). Mercy on me! what a terrible steep old stair case; I'm up at last. [Enters]. Oh dear! Where's the Doctor—Is that the great man that pro∣mises to cure me with a touch, gratis?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Yes—the worse you are, the sooner you'll be well.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Dear me! how lucky it is that I'm so bad—may I speak to him? he seems quite taken up with himself; I expected to have seen the whole town at his door.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Hush! no noise—this is a private day—don't interrupt his meditations; and above all, mind how you tread—the whole room is one electrical mat∣ter. If you touch a nail, you'll be convuls'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Oh lord!—lay hold of me. (Pallet puts out the lamp)—Dungeons and death—why we are almost in the dark.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: In the dark—to be sure—that's the way your great physicians practise—always in the dark—now, Sir, prepare yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Yes—I—I—will—what must I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Draw near the Doctor—as the first proof of his art. He'll put you to excessive pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Excessive pain—Oh lud! I'm in a cold sweat already.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Never fear—you'll soon be warm'd—now Doctor. Here stands your patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Bring out de surprising magnetic chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles
SP.P: (bringing it). Aye, this is the panacea—this is the universal remedy. Come, Sir, lose no time—get into it—[aside] once fix him there, and I'll be off.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Fix de patient, and go fetch de instruments.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Instruments!—Oh mercy!—I shall be cut up alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Quick, quick, lose no time, I hav'n't a moment to spare.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Why, what are you about?—wou'd you truss me up like a rabbit?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: So, he seems pretty safe; and now to secure his Lady;—Doctor, don't lose sight of your patient. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: What are you going to do, Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Now for de cure—first, dis asiatic cap must be put over your face—come, no struggle.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta
SP.P: (aside). I met Sir Charles rushing out of this door in such a dress, and in such haste, he cou'd n't answer me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Take it away—take it away; mercy Doc∣tor! What, wou'd you iron mask me?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Here's something mysterious—perhaps Saville is in the plot.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Put on de cap, or I fall give you endless pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: I won't—I won't be blind-folded.—Oh lud, will no body help me.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta
SP.P: (oversets the table with all the Electrical Ap∣paratus) I'll aid the confusion, to secure our retreat.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Oh lud!—Oh dear—the worlds at an end—We shall be all burnt in our beds. Help! help! [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet
SP.P: (with the dark lanthern looking about). Zounds, what a crash! Sure some one must have got into the room.—Damn the chair (tumbles over it), I don't see any body—I'm as much terrified as Flurry himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta
SP.P: [aside]. Are you so? then it's high time I shou'd take courage.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Well, I have finished my Doctorship—and so perriwig be gone.—Now, if he does but suc∣ceed with Mrs. Flurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Who succeed with Mrs. Flurry?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Oh forgive me my sins.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Peace, blockhead; who is to suceeed with Mrs. Flurry—Sir Charles, or Saville?

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Dear, sweet, Sir.—

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Don't prevaricate.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: I won't. Saville, did you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Aye, Saville, Sir.—Come, confess, or I'll do you more mischief—than you intended to that old trembletonian.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: If I betray, Sir Charles, I ruin every thing (aside), better lay it to Saville (aside). Well, Sir, since I must confess the truth, the whole is a scheme of Mr. Saville's.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: So!

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: He prevail'd on, Sir Charles, and me, to lure Mr. Flurry into this old house, that he might pass an agreeable half hour with his wife, and Sir Charles is now gone to inform him of our success.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Conduct me to them then.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: What, Sir, wou'd you spoil sport?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Sport do you call it—Shew me the way this instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: I will, Sir!—Oh lord! I never was so frighten'd in all my life—if I can but get safe into the street, little Pallet will soon brush off (aside).

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
The Outside of the House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Augusta and Pallet from the Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Come along, Sir; no more electrical tricks, if you please, follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: To be sure, Sir—but first let me secure Old Puzzlepate from following us [aside].

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Why do you loter so?—Come Sir, lead the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: That I will, and make away too—if I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Charming fellow, Sir Charles! a few more such Baronets wou'd support a new Doctors Commons. Crim. con. as plenty as hops—Old Flurry little thinks what he's about now.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry
SP.P: (from the window). Help! Help!—where am I?

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: What, my dear Mr. Flurry up in the cock loft.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: My dear friend Liti—is it you—where are we?

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Where are we?—in Knight Rider-street, Doctors Commons.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: What, are you come to the Doctor to be cur'd with a touch, gratis?

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: A touch, gratis—Oh no,—that wou'd not do for me. When I am touch'd, I always take.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Oh dear, how shall I find the way out of this confounded old mansion. Will you step up and assist me?

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Swift as thought—but ho—proceedings are stop'd—the door is lock'd—it will be impossible to join issue on this occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: The door lock'd! O mercy, I shall be rob∣bed and murdered. I'll try to get out of the window.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Heaven forbid; you'll break your neck. I may lose a client (aside). There's a ladder yonder, by that house that's repairing. I'll go and fetch it di∣rectly. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Be quick, be quick! While I'm here, my wife may be going off with her gallant. Oh! if ever I think of a touch again.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: Now, dear Sir, make haste and descend; but take care; one false step you know—

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I know—I'll be after them—hold it fast, Mr. Proctor. Am I safe? There now—I'll be after them as quick as a lamplighter. (Runs out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P: (With the ladder on his shoulder.) Gad, I think I look more like a lamplighter—Ha! ha! A whimsical suit this. No matter; a good proctor can carry any thing. [Exit with ladder.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Flurry and Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Surely, my dearest madam, you are not serious.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Hav'n't I reason to be serious, Sir Charles? I am not the dupe you wish'd me. My servant told me, Mr. Flurry was here; and I insist that you let me enter the house directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: I tell you he is not there; but if he was, you would not come in search of your husband? Why if this were known, it would ruin you in polite life forever.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Thanks to fortune, I have escaped from my troublesome companion, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Don't prevent me, Sir Charles; I insist on looking after him; Sir open the door imme∣diately.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: What, put man and wife in the same piece?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: I will no longer be trifled with.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Think of the difference between the lover and the husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Yes, a good copy, and a bad original.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Unhand me, I say; nay, then 'tis time to call help! help!

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: How! a lady in distress—release her this instant, or by heavens—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Silence, Saville—don't interrupt pas∣time.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Sir Charles, is it you? I hope then there is no occasion for my interference.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Sir, if you have any spirit or huma∣nity, you will prevent my being detain'd any longer from my husband, who is lock'd up in that house.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Mrs. Flurry, the friend of Augusta! Why, Sir Charles, you wou'd not keep the lady from her husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet.
SP.P: Her husband! the old story. Harkye,—hackney'd as the pave—notorious, common—

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Stand by, Sir, I know the lady well; and the respect that is her due. Say no more—but let her enter the house directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Zounds, Saville, is this your friend∣ship?

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Friendship! I am sorry, Sir Charles, to find you so unworthy of it. Come, Madam, favour me, with your hand; there—be assur'd while I have life, no power on earth shall interrupt you. (Puts her in.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Death and fury! Do you know what you have done, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Yes, released a lady from violence; and, perhaps, saved my friend from dishonour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Mighty well—I understand this irony—but let me follow her—or by all that's—

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Spare your warmth, Sir Charles; you have heard my determination.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Then you shall hear mine—let me pass this instant; or abide the consequences.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: The first I will not—the last I'm prepar'd for.

SP.SPEAKER: Pallet,
SP.P: (with a tuck stick). Come out my two edged brush—you shall give the finishing stroke, I warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville▪
SP.P: Is this your usual bravery!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: No matter, Sir—I will pass.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Saville, in danger; let me forget my sex and fly to save him—(Placing herself on the side of Saville.)

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry
SP.P: (without). Oh lud! I can't find her any where.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Augusta and Flurry coming—confusion—we must retire; Saville, you shall repent this in∣sult. [Sir Charles and Pallet Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: I have much to repent of; but this I shall ever reflect upon with pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: I have lost my wife—I have lost my wife—and now I have lost the Proctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Oh! Mr. Flurry, how happy I am to find you; where have you been—how did you get out of the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: How did you get into it. Where's your gallant—Oh if I cou'd but find the proctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta,
SP.P: (aside). So, all is as I suspected, and I have been fighting in the defence of a rival.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, I have been much oblig'd to this gentleman in your absence, and while I live his generosity must be engraved on my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta,
SP.P: (aside). A very passionate acknowledge∣ment indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Ha! what am I oblig'd to more gentlemen than one. I thought, Mr. Saville had been attach'd to my ward, and not to my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta,
SP.P: (aside.) So I thought too.

SP.SPEAKER: Flurry.
SP.P: Oh lud! at this rate, my poor nerves will be play'd upon by every fellow in town—however I am now going to a place where they will put me in a way to reward you all—Doctors Commons for me—Oh! if I cou'd but catch the proctor. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Mr. Saville, your most obedient, I shall find a better time to thank you. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: I suppose so.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: How comes it Chevalier, after what has passed we meet as friends—tho' you wou'd not fight with me, I see you dare to draw in my defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: The truth is—I am a strange creature, Saville; nay, so very contradictory, that at times you wou'd almost think me a woman—I bullied before your uncle to prove your temper—I offer'd the thou∣sand pounds to try your generosity, and I cou'd do no less than assist you in your love affairs, especially when the lady is so deserving.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: You mistake, I was her protector only, not her lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Come, come, confess—She is a very beautiful woman, and you wanted to mar Sir Charles's happiness by making your own—Ha! what's the matter with you? Heavens! there's blood upon your arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: I know it—a mere scratch, not worth a thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Not worth a thought—Oh here take my handkerchief, bind it directly—Come, you must—you shall—Nay then I'll bind it myself. Let me see! Heavens! What a wound—Oh Saville!

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: What agitates you?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: The sight of blood dissolves me—it pene∣trates my soul. I can't support it.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: This from an enemy?

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: I am not your enemy Saville, I'm your friend; one whose heart bleeds for every wound in yours—But while we talk you grow fainter. Let me conduct you to Mr. Flurry's—there perhaps, the lady who loves you, will console you.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Why will you misconceive me, I never loved but one nor ever can; the angel I was attach'd to, was as superior to the rest of her sex—But I'll trou∣ble you no longer—farewel.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Stay! let me accompany you.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: No, I have private business, and will de∣tain you no further.—Give me your hand Chevalier, you are a generous fellow, and I feel much distress'd from the thought of having injur'd you—we shall meet again. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P:
Poor Saville!—He little thinks how well I know where his private business is; but as his law∣yer
happens to be mine too, I hope to get possession of his remaining property by to-morrow at farthest.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk.
SP.P: Sir, my master, Counsellor Gab, hath order'd me to run after you with a letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: From Saville's lawyer, the very man I was thinking of. (Reads).

LETTER.P: “”Dearest of ladies. Circuits—nisi, prius—mani∣fold briefs, and some motions of course, oblige me to move out of town—must defer client Saville's dis∣tress till return—hope no distress to you, can but be more done up.—Have said the needful, cou'd say more, but desist, I am a man of few words.

SP.P: Bless me, this delay may be fatal—Saville's circum∣stances can never suffer him to wait for this man of few words. He will most likely apply elsewhere, and my plans be entirely overset. Let me consider, I have it.—As I find Saville has no knowledge of his lawyer's person, I'll pop my friend, the counsellors tye, over this little noddle of mine—borrow his cham∣bers in his absence, and prove myself as wise in one own as another. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
Chambers in the Temple.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter a Lawyer's Clerk, shewing in Saville.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk.
SP.P: PRAY Sir, walk in, I expect my master from Westminster Hall immediately—He beg'd you wou'd not go away.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: I believe it is somewhat past the time ap∣pointed.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk.
SP.P: I dare say, Sir, he'll be here in a minute, pray Sir sit down.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Thank you friend—I shall amuse myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk,
SP.P: (aside). I wonder how, madam, my sham master will escape being discover'd—but women and lawyers talk equally fast—therefore her task won't be so difficult. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: My distresses croud upon me so rapidly—I know not whither to turn myself—the money I am now about to raise, is my last stake, half of that is gone already, my uncle has refus'd every assistance; but what does it signify—I have lost all hope of my Augusta, and the charm of living is no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta
SP.P: (as a counsellor) without. Thomas pay the coachman sixpence, counsellor Coaxem pays the other tester—We stopp'd ten yards short of Temple Bar on purpose (Enters). Your name, Sir, I presume is Saville—Sorry I have been so detain'd and stopp'd, by cause why, at Westminster Hall—but if so be as it shou'd be so, as that I have not made you wait—there is nothing lost, by not putting in appearance.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: No apology, sir, is necessary, I assure you, you know my business, and I understand can do it—the deeds are all in your hands, and you approve them▪ your letter so informs me.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Sir, my name it counsellor Gab—and when counsellor Gab says a thing—that is when a thing is said—then he says no more about it—you want to find, raise, and make up a sum of money. Coun∣sellor Gab has client to that effect—You shew cause of security, and then effect follows cause, as in cases out of number.—I am a man of few words.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: I like few words full as well as yourself—I am in want of money, and have shewn cause as you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: True, want of money is like a chancery fuit, a trial of patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: I perceive it is indeed—but if every thing is ready, there can be no occasion for further delay, and in that case, I have only to satisfy you.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: As to the money, all that remains is a bill on bankers in form due at sight, payable to bearer, perfectly legal, but avoids stamps, and shall be sent to morrow; but if so be as that you like, wish, or re∣quest mode that is different—Counsellor Gab is always ready to satisfy client, without making use of many words—and if you wish for an opinion—

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: By no means, Mr. Counsellor, I wou'd not wish to trespass on your time

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: You're right; a trespass on the case is as I said before. Vide cases out of number, suits, pleas, costs, taxes and demurrers; for instance, if a man loses his mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: I beg you will not trouble yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Or to prove clearer, suppose plaintiff has lost fortune to sharpers, the action—

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Needs no rhetoric to condemn it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk.
SP.P: A lady desires to speak with you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: A lady! well desire the lady to walk in.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: I fear I intrude.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Oh, not in the least; the lady shall be dispatch'd immediately; I never throw away my time upon women.

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: If I may be so inquisitous as to ask, your name is Mr. Lawyer Gab. I waited on you from my mistress, Miss Augusta Melmouth. Lord, Mr. Saville here; who would have supposed it? But I beg pardon, as Orestes said to his friend, Pilgarlic—

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Well, what of your lady? don't be afraid of me. I hope she is well, and I ought to wish that she is happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: Now to act my part as well as my mistress (aside). Nay, as for the matter of that, my young lady wants nothing—that is, nothing more than other young ladies want too. She wish'd to know whether Mr. Lawyer here, had examin'd the marriage articles on her side, and whether Mr. Lawyer on t'other side had examin'd them too; and whether they were ready on both sides;—and so I came to enquire, like the Busy Body there, in the Way of the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: What did you say? Marriage articles!—Sure your young lady, Augusta, is not going to be married?

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, and why not? If gentlemen deal cards one way, ladies must play their cards another, as Skippio says, in Gil Blas. Don't you think so, Mr. Lawyer.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Skippio! Never saw an opinion of his in my life; but as to cards, if two females engage with one gentleman, it's odds but he'll be put to his trumps.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: You seem merry Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Yes, during term, smile and talk—in va∣cation, sad and silent.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Permit me, Mrs. Diary to ask only one question—Who is destin'd to be the possessor of that heart the proudest might a spire to; and which once the humblest was bold enough to solicit.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P:
I swear by the a izes, Mr. Saville, but you seem as if, as how you wan ted to take a client out of
my hands, if the young lady chuses to marry. If A. wants to join issue with B. what has D. to do with it?

SP.SPEAKER: Diary.
SP.P: Aye, what has D. to do with issue? So, pray let us alone Mr. Saville; and do you, Mr. Law∣yer, be pleas'd to send home the marriage ceremonies, that my mistress may put her hand to them as soon as possible; for when we women take a thing in our heads, we are determined to go through with it, as Caesar says in his dictionary.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: I ought certainly to beg your pardon for the earnestness of my enquiries; but the Lady men∣tion'd, was one, whom I was once weak enough—But no matter—I shall only intrude further on your pa∣tience.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Not in the least, I feel interested in that warmth which does you so much honour—but perhaps the Lady may be ignorant of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: That is not now material—Bless me, I have exceeded my time; I have an appointment with Sir Charles Chouse, which obliges me to be punctual.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Obliges you to be punctual—there is surely something in your manner that seems to indicate, what I hope is not true, that you have an affair of ho∣nour on your hands—Can I be of service?

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Sure, Sir, I ought to be surpris'd at the alteration of your stile.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Oh dear, Sir, we lawyers have two lan∣guages, one for forms and courts, another for feelings and friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: I am oblig'd to you, Sir, for the compli∣ment, but all I have to re quest is, that you will send the money to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Counsellor Gab has promis'd, and per∣formance follows of course. Would I cou'd detain him till I had seen Sir Charles (aside). Sir, on second thoughts, if so be the laws delay is irksome, as necessity has no law, please to wait in that library till I return, and I'll endeavour to get the sum specified on notice immediate.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: It is impossible for me to stay—to-morrow must suffice.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Let me advise you, Sir, to tarry—shan't be long—you'll find pretty recreation in my library—Statutes at Large—Burn's Justice—new edition—Law∣yer's Vade-mecum—Every Man his own Attorney—Pleadings at Nisi Prius.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Very instructive—but I can't profit by them at present—Your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, stay a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: It is not in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: Do, take counsel.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: I tell you I have had enough of counsel.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, you don't doubt my ability.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: Not in the art of talking, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: If you did but know me, you wou'd n't wonder at my excellence in that.

SP.SPEAKER: Saville.
SP.P: I wonder at nothing in a lawyer, but the difficulty of getting rid of him. Adieu. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Augusta.
SP.P: I will but stay to disengage myself from these law encumbrances, and try if I can't be before∣hand with Sir Charles, for I am determin'd to prevent this dreaded rencontre, if possible. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
A large Exhibition Room in Pallet's House, with various Pictures, and a whole length of Mrs. Flurry. A Win∣dow with a Curtain down, &c. a Sopha, &c.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Litigamus with a large pocket-book and pencil.

SP.SPEAKER: Litig.
SP.P:
Here am I, still upon the look out in Master Pallet's seminary, tho' he himself is no party to this motion; for his friend, Sir Charles, I find, tho' a good maker of clients, is but a sorry one himself, there∣fore I am gone over to my first opinion.—Old Flurry has got it into his head that his Lady is coming here again, to meet her paramour, so he has sent me slily to take notes of proceeding. Ah bless, all billing and
cooing, I say! they are the sack and sugar of Doctors Commons—give me a dashing wife to lead up the dance, and a good husband to pay the piper—Sure I hear somebody—I had better conceal myself—it will look so treacherous, to pretend friendship, and then dis∣cover the parties—No, at all events—I'll betray with honour—Where shall I go?—Oh! aye—aye—this so∣pha will do the business. [Conceals himself under it.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Flurry and Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: Leave me, Sir.—I will no more be deceiv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Charles.
SP.P: Nay, my dear Mrs. Flurry, hear reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flurry.
SP.P: No, Sir, I'll hear nothing; I insist on your pursuing me no further. I had never ventur'd here again had I not seen you at the end of the street, and stepp'd in on purpose to avoid you.
